head.title: Charles Atlas Complaint Held as Legal Weakling

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Marketing, Advertising and PR

hedline.hl1: Charles Atlas Complaint Held as Legal Weakling

abstract.p: Federal Judge Naomi Reice Buchwald dismisses suit by Charles Atlas Ltd claiming character in short-lived DC comic Flex Mentallo was based on company's comic book ads portraying 97-pound weakling who thrashes sand-kicking bully after taking company's bodybuilding course; rules company failed to raise issue within six-year statute of limitations; also finds comic was parody of ads and not subject to suit for trademark infringement; photo (M)

block.p: Charles Atlas might have been one of America's most famous musclemen, ably taking on bullies who kicked sand in his face at the beach. But this week, a federal judge treated his company like a 97-pound weakling and threw it out of court.

The company, which markets a body-building course popularized in part through generations of comic book advertisements, had gone to court claiming that a character in a short-lived DC comic was taken from Atlas's famous campaign ''The Insult That Made a Man out of Mac.''

Charles Atlas might have been one of America's most famous musclemen, ably taking on bullies who kicked sand in his face at the beach. But this week, a federal judge treated his company like a 97-pound weakling and threw it out of court.

The company, which markets a body-building course popularized in part through generations of comic book advertisements, had gone to court claiming that a character in a short-lived DC comic was taken from Atlas's famous campaign ''The Insult That Made a Man out of Mac.''

The ad told the brief story of Mac, the 97-pound weakling, and a bully who kicks sand in his face. Mac, humiliated by the sand kicking, takes the Charles Atlas course, becomes a hulking giant and returns to thrash the bully. In the final panel, the words ''Hero of the Beach'' hover over Mac's head, while his girlfriend looks on.

In 1991, DC Comics published a book featuring a character called Flex Mentallo. The comic book featured a vignette titled ''Musclebound -- The Secret Origin of Flex Mentallo.'' Like Mac, Flex started out as a weakling, was humiliated by a bully and gained super strength through exercise. But after beating the bully, Flex turns on his girlfriend and beats her, proclaiming, ''I don't need a tramp like you anymore.''
Charles Atlas Ltd. claimed the Flex Mentallo character owed its origin to the Mac advertising campaign, and that DC's portrayal had damaged the good will gained by the original ad.

But Judge Naomi Reice Buchwald, of Federal District Court in Manhattan, rejected Atlas's argument. She granted DC's motion for a summary judgment and dismissed the case on Tuesday. Judge Buchwald ruled that Charles Atlas had failed to raise the issue within the six-year statute of limitations required by such cases, and she also found that the DC comic was a parody of the Charles Atlas ads, and therefore not subject to a lawsuit for trademark infringement.

Lillian Laserson, vice president and general counsel for DC Comics, welcomed the decision, saying the episode was meant as a parody. ''We meant no harm to the Charles Atlas company, nor do I think we caused any harm,'' she said.
But the lawyer for Charles Atlas said DC Comics should not have copied the ad campaign.

''It is our position, whether or not he had turned around and beat up his own girlfriend after he became an Atlas man, it would have been an infringement,'' said Seth Akabas, a lawyer whose firm represented Charles Atlas Ltd.
The company survives the body builder Charles Atlas, who died in 1972. He was often featured in the ads in his bathing suit.
